Command-line interface tools and how to build them.
Attempts to assign meaning to words and phrases.
The FSF is the [Free Software Foundation](https://www.fsf.org/).
Posts about projects I have worked on.
Simple Object Access Protocol. It wasn't very simple.
[SQLite](https://www.sqlite.org/) is the world's [most widely deployed database engine](https://www.sqlite.org/mostdeployed.html).
Talks I've given at various conferences around the world.

Small tools I have built, many of which are hosted on my [tools.simonwillison.net](https://tools.simonwillison.net/) GitHub Pages site backed by my [simonw/tools](https://github.com/simonw/tools) repository.
"[AI is whatever hasn't been done yet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_effect)"—Larry Tesler
[Datasette](https://datasette.io/) is an open source tool for exploring and publishing data.
I publish weeknotes once every two or three weeks documenting what I've been working on recently.
The SaaS hosted version of Datasette, at [datasette.cloud](https://www.datasette.cloud/)

[Git scraping](https://simonwillison.net/2020/Oct/9/git-scraping/) is a technique where data is scraped from an external source into a Git repository in order to record changes to that data over time.
[sqlite-utils](https://sqlite-utils.datasette.io/) is a Python library and command-line utility for creating and manipulating SQLite databases.
[Django SQL Dashboard](https://django-sql-dashboard.datasette.io) adds a read-only PostgreSQL SQL dashboard interface to a Django project.
I sometimes publish extended annotated versions of the release notes for my projects.
Datasette as an Electron desktop application, at [datasette.io/desktop](https://datasette.io/desktop)
[git-history](https://github.com/simonw/git-history) is a tool for analyzing data scraped to a GitHub repository using SQLite.
[s3-credentials](https://s3-credentials.readthedocs.io/) is a CLI tool for creating and managing credentials for S3 buckets.
[shot-scraper](https://shot-scraper.datasette.io/) is a command-line utility for taking screenshots of websites and scraping content from them using JavaScript.
Datasette running entirely in the browser using Pyodide and WebAssembly, at [lite.datasette.io](https://lite.datasette.io/)
[OpenAI](https://openai.com/) build [ChatGPT](https://chatgpt.com/) and the GPT series of Large Language Models.
The [Python Software Foundation](https://www.python.org/psf-landing/) is the non-profit organization devoted to advancing open source technology related to the Python programming language.
The subtle art and craft of effectively prompting and building software on top of LLMs.

**Prompt Injection** is a security attack against applications built on top of Large Language Models, [introduced here](https://simonwillison.net/2022/Sep/12/prompt-injection/) and further described in [this series of posts](https://simonwillison.net/series/prompt-injection/).
Machine learning systems that can generate new content: text, images, audio, video and more.
[GitHub Copilot](https://github.com/features/copilot) is GitHub's extension for VS Code that uses LLMs to provide context-driven code completion suggestions.
The [Llama](https://www.llama.com/) family of open weight LLMs from Meta/Facebook AI research.
LLMs that can run on consumer hardware like laptops or mobile phones.

Large Language Models (LLMs) are the class of technology behind generative text AI systems like OpenAI's [ChatGPT](https://simonwillison.net/tags/chatgpt/), Google's [Gemini](https://simonwillison.net/tags/gemini/) and Anthropic's [Claude](https://simonwillison.net/tags/claude/).

Using AI tools such as Large Language Models to help write code. [Vibe coding](https://simonwillison.net/tags/vibe-coding/) is the less responsible subset of this. See **[Here’s how I use LLMs to help me write code](https://simonwillison.net/2025/Mar/11/using-llms-for-code/)** for a description of my process.
See [Embeddings: What they are and why they matter](https://simonwillison.net/2023/Oct/23/embeddings/).
[LLM](https://llm.datasette.io/) is my command-line tool for running prompts against Large Language Models.
[Anthropic](https://www.anthropic.com/) are the AI research company behind [Claude](https://claude.ai/).
[Claude](https://www.anthropic.com/claude) is Anthropic's family of Large Language Models.
Annotated versions of talks I have given, with extensive notes and additional links. Here's [how I make these](https://simonwillison.net/2023/Aug/6/annotated-presentations/).
[Mistral AI](https://mistral.ai/) release both openly licensed and API-hosted Language Models.
[GitHub Codespaces](https://github.com/features/codespaces) provides cloud development environments accessible through a browser.
[Nomic AI](https://www.nomic.ai) develop various interesting AI projects, including [GPT4All](https://gpt4all.io/) and powerful [embedding models](https://gpt4all.io/).
[Val Town](https://www.val.town/) provides a web interface for building, running and deploying server-side JavaScript apps.
The Gemini family of multimodal LLMs developed by Google DeepMind.

ChatGPT Code Interpreter is a mode of [ChatGPT](https://chatgpt.com/) (and now [Claude](https://simonwillison.net/2025/Sep/9/claude-code-interpreter/)) that allows it to write and then execute Python code in a sandboxed environment. OpenAI sometimes call this feature [data analysis](https://help.openai.com/en/articles/8437071-data-analysis-with-chatgpt).
Supply chain security, most notably for open source packages.
The [Command R](https://cohere.com/command) family of language models from Cohere.

RAG stands for **Retrieval Augmented Generation**. It's a trick where you find additional context relevant to the user's request using other means (such as full-text or vector search) and populate that context as part of the prompt to a Large Language Model.
**Slop** describes AI-generated content that is both *unrequested* and *unreviewed*. See [Slop is the new name for unwanted AI-generated content](https://simonwillison.net/2024/May/8/slop/).
Microsoft's [Phi family](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/products/phi) of small Large Language Models.
Microsoft Recall is a feature planned for Windows 11 that allows users to search through automated screenshots taken of their previous activity on their PC.

**Exfiltration attacks** are [prompt injection](https://simonwillison.net/tags/promptinjection/) attacks against chatbots that have access to private information, where that information is [exfiltrated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_exfiltration) by the attacker. One common form of this is **Markdown exfiltration** where an attacker tricks the bot into rendering a Markdown image that leaks data encoded in the URL to an external server.
Microsoft's partially open source text editor [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/).
[BeeWare](https://beeware.org/) "allows you to write your app in Python and release it on multiple platforms".
[llamafile](https://github.com/Mozilla-Ocho/llamafile) provides a mechanism to distribute and run LLMs as a single file.
LLMs that can also be used to interpret images and video, such as GPT-4o, Claude 3 and Gemini Pro.
[CLIP](https://github.com/openai/CLIP) is an embedding model by OpenAI that supports comparisons between images and text.

Tool use is when an LLM is instructed to occasionally request that an external tool be run on its behalf, with the result passed back to the model for further processing. Sometimes also known as function calling, and one of several ideas that might be referred to as "agents".
Data used to train LLMs and other machine learning models.

A feature of [Claude](https://claude.ai/) where it can create shareable, executable HTML and JavaScript pages. See [Everything I built with Claude Artifacts this week](https://simonwillison.net/2024/Oct/21/claude-artifacts/) for several detailed examples.
Evaluations and benchmarks of AI systems, for example to compare different models and prompting strategies.
[uv](https://github.com/astral-sh/uv) is an "extremely fast Python package and project manager, written in Rust".

CORS is [Cross-origin resource sharing](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS), a mechanism by which websites can make APIs available to JavaScript running on other domains around the web.
[Qwen](https://huggingface.co/Qwen) is the Large Language Model family built by Alibaba Cloud.
[Marimo](https://marimo.io/) is an open-source reactive notebook for Python.
[DJP](https://djp.readthedocs.io/) is a plugin system for Django.
The [MLX framework](https://github.com/ml-explore/mlx) for running machine learning models on Apple Silicon.
GPUs aren't just for graphics anymore.
AI agents can mean [a lot of different things](https://simonwillison.net/2025/Sep/18/agents/). These days I think of them as **LLMs calling tools in a loop to achieve a goal**.
Posts about the pricing of various LLMs. See also my [pricing calculator](https://tools.simonwillison.net/llm-prices).
[Ollama](https://ollama.com/) is a tool for downloading and running Large Language Models.
[SmolLM](https://huggingface.co/blog/smollm) is a series of small Large Language Models by Hugging Face.
Using LLMs to extract structured data from unstructured text and images.

My [benchmark for LLMs](https://simonwillison.net/2025/Jun/6/six-months-in-llms/): "Generate an SVG of a pelican riding a bicycle".

"User might be a kid playing with words" [according to Qwen3-4B-Thinking](https://simonwillison.net/2025/Aug/10/qwen3-4b/).
[Pydantic](https://docs.pydantic.dev/) is a data validation library for Python based around Python's type annotation feature.

Improving performance of LLMs through spending more tokens "reasoning" about a problem, as seen in OpenAI's [o-series](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/reasoning), DeepSeek's [R1](https://arxiv.org/abs/2501.12948), Qwen's [QwQ](https://github.com/QwenLM/QwQ), Google's [Gemini 2.5](https://blog.google/technology/google-deepmind/gemini-model-thinking-updates-march-2025/) and Anthropic's [Claude 3.7 Sonnet](https://blog.google/technology/google-deepmind/gemini-model-thinking-updates-march-2025/).
[DeepSeek](https://www.deepseek.com/) is an AI lab from Chinese hedge fund [High-Flyer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-Flyer_(company)).
Some LLM providers offer a feature where common prompt prefixes can be cached, providing a performance boost and price reduction.
Tracking how LLMs are getting better at accepting large amounts of input.
[llama.cpp](https://github.com/ggerganov/llama.cpp) is an LLM inference library written in C/C++.
[PleIAs](https://pleias.fr/) is a French AI lab specializing in "energy-efficient LLMs for information-intensive and highly-regulated industries".
LLMs that can output non-textual media content such as images an audio.
We run these public office hours community livestream sessions on the [Datasette Discord](https://datasette.io/discord).
[Limbo](https://github.com/tursodatabase/limbo) is an implementation of a SQLite-compatible database engine in Rust.
The `SQLITE_BUSY` error - if you're seeing it in WAL mode that's probably because you aren't using `BEGIN IMMEDIATE` on all of your transactions that perform at least one write.
The Grok family of LLMs from [xAI](https://x.ai/).
Ai2 is the [Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence](https://allenai.org/).
Times when I went on a podcast.
The pattern where LLM tools put together a report based on many searches chained together. Also the name of similar products from Google Gemini, OpenAI and Perplexity.
Google's [Gemma family](https://ai.google.dev/gemma) of openly licensed Large Language Models.
Ethical concerns related to building and using AI systems.

As [defined here](https://simonwillison.net/2025/Feb/6/andrej-karpathy/) - not the same thing as [AI-assisted programming](https://simonwillison.net/tags/ai-assisted-programming/), though there's some overlap.
[Model Context Proocol](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/introduction) (MCP) is an open protocol that standardizes how applications provide context to and tools to LLMs.
[files-to-prompt](https://github.com/simonw/files-to-prompt) concatenate a directory full of files into a single prompt for use with LLMs.
The [Chatbot Arena](https://lmarena.ai/) ranks LLMs based on votes from a community of users for the best response from anonymized model pairs.
Using LLMs to build better search engines, and providing search tool access to LLMs.
There's a conspiracy theory that apps on your phone are serving you targeted ads based on spying on what you say through your microphone. I do not believe that this is true.
Guessing the location of an image based on visual clues.
The weird craft of establishing a personality for an AI system.
How much energy is used by AI systems?

[Semantic diffusion](https://martinfowler.com/bliki/SemanticDiffusion.html) occurs when a new piece of jargon inevitably takes on an unintended and incorrect definition as it uncontrollably spreads beyond its origin.
How Large Language Models split text up into tokens.
LLMs sometimes just make things up!
[GitHub Issues](https://github.com/features/issues) is GitHub's issue tracker and project planning software suite.
Posts about my [weekly newsletter](https://simonw.substack.com/) or [monthly newsletter for sponsors](https://github.com/sponsors/simonw).
Systems where an LLM writes code which is then compiled, executed, tested or otherwise exercised by tools in a loop.
[Claude Code](https://www.anthropic.com/claude-code) is Anthropic's terminal coding agent, enabling Claude to run tools in a loop on your own machine.
Posts where I do a deep dive into an academic paper.

Any time you grant an LLM-based system access to private data, exposure to untrusted content, and the ability to externally communicate you have [a nasty security hole](https://simonwillison.net/2025/Jun/16/the-lethal-trifecta/). See [exfiltration-attacks](https://simonwillison.net/tags/exfiltration-attacks/) for more examples.
[LM Studio](https://lmstudio.ai/) is a desktop application for running local LLMs.
Times I got quoted in the press.
[Smarty](https://www.smarty.net/) is a template engine for PHP.
The hidden prompts that LLM applications use to specify how they should behave.
See also my tags for [Qwen](https://simonwillison.net/tags/qwen/) and [DeepSeek](https://simonwillison.net/tags/deepseek).
Results for my simple LLM benchmark "Write an HTML and JavaScript page implementing space invaders"
OpenAI's family of open weight models.

**Asynchronous coding agents** are tools like OpenAI Codex and Jules that can be set a task and will then check out and iterate on code in their own hosted environment and submit the proposed change as a pull request.
[Artificial Analysis](https://artificialanalysis.ai/) is an independent AI benchmarking and analysis company.
[Jules](https://jules.google/) is an asynchronous coding agent from Google.
[Rich](https://github.com/Textualize/rich) is a Python library for building terminal applications.
[Moonshot](https://www.moonshot.cn/) are the Chinese AI lab behind the Kimi family of LLMs.
OpenAI's [Codex CLI](https://github.com/openai/codex) tool, not the same thing as [Codex cloud](https://developers.openai.com/codex/cloud).
Features that add "memory" to LLM systems, allowing them to consult information from previous interactions.

When I receive value (financial or in-kind) connected to my writing such as travel, accommodation, event access, review units, reimbursements, or honoraria, I disclose it here. See also [my disclosures policy](https://simonwillison.net/about/#disclosures).
The pattern where an LLM agent fires up a "sub-agent" - a separate LLM agent with a fresh token context that solves a single problem and provides the answer back to the parent.
CSP - Content Security Policy - is an HTTP header mechanism for [controlling what resources can be loaded by a page](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Guides/CSP).
Generative AI models that output video, usually from a text and/or image input.
Tools that build you a full working application based on a prompt.
Times when I live blogged during an event.
Computer use models are AI models specifically designed to operate a computer via a GUI.
Running multiple coding agents in parallel
Originally introduced [by Anthropic](https://simonwillison.net/2025/Oct/16/claude-skills/), Skills are Markdown files that teach LLM systems new tricks.
Agent tools that live in web browsers.
Times I got something wrong and issued a retraction.
